details.title: A New Method to Determine the Reliability Comparability for Products, Components, and Systems in Reliability Testing

p: Wei-Ting Kary Chien received his Ph.D degree from Texas A&M University, College Station, Texas, USA. He is an Associate Vice President, Quality & Reliability, Shanghai, SMIC. He is currently involved in semiconductor quality engineering, SPC, calibration, product & process reliability tests, assembly, testing, wafer-level reliability (WLR), build-in reliability (BIR) activities & system development, failure analysis, and statistical modeling & training. He has several publications on well-known journals and conferences including IEEE Trans. Reliability, IEEE Trans. Semiconductor Manufacturing, Naval Logistic Quarterly, Communications in Statistics, IIE Transactions, Microelectronics Reliability, RAMS, VLSI, IRPS, ISTFA, IRW, JEDEX, and co-authors a book “Reliability, Yield, and Stress Burn-In - A Unified Approach for Microelectronics Systems Manufacturing and Software Development”. He holds several patents on reliability hardware, methodology, test-key designs and is Associate Editor of IEEE Transactions on Reliability, a life member of the Phi-Tau-Phi Scholastic Honored Society, and Senior Member of IEEE.

Siyuan Frank Yang Siyuan Frank Yang received the B.S., and M.S. respectively in 1982, and 1985 in physics from Fudan University, Shanghai, China; the M.S. in 1989 in nuclear engineering; and the Ph.D. in 1994 in materials science and engineering from University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. He then joined Applied Materials, and also worked for Aplex Inc, Intel later in the areas on IC process development of PVD, oxide and silicon etch, CMP and photo mask repair and Statistical DOE consultation from 1995 to 2001. He received Innovation and Excellence Award in 1996 from Applied Materials from his patent, his contribution in PVD, and papers published in internal Engineering Technology conferences. He joined SMIC in 2001 working on the thin film module, process integration, statistician and reliability engineering. Now, he is Assistant Director in Reliability Engineering in charge of wafer level reliability control and at the same time, serves as a statistician in SMIC.

details.abstract: A method is proposed in this paper to determine whether a product, a component, or a system in reliability life testing has a longer lifetime than the other. We propose two indices to compare reliability. The comparison is also distribution-free; i.e., it does not require the assumption on the lifetime distributions. A comparability index that is derived by integrating the weighted difference between the reliability functions of the two groups under comparison is named the "Better or Worse" (BOW) index. The second comparability index that is derived by calculating the overlapping area under the two distributions in comparison is named "Reliability Comparability" (RC) to quantify the degree of similarity between the two distributions. These two new indices are compared with the conventional methods currently used in the IC industries. Practical applications in lifetime-type reliability comparison are also illustrated in this paper

references.title: Proceedings of Hawaii International Conference on Statistics 2002

context.text: To compare process parameters, Wang [1] proposed an index, “sameness” (whose corresponding US patent was filed and granted in 2004 [2]), in 2002, and he defined “sameness” as the “normalized” sum of the integral (both shaded areas in Fig. 1) under both distributions from a predetermined lower limit “C” to upper limit “D” as in Fig. 1, where “C” is the lower \$3\sigma\$ control limit of one population (Fab A in Fig. 1), and “D” is the upper \$3\sigma\$ control limit of the other (Fab B in Fig. 1).

Sameness makes quantitative comparisons possible, and, to further facilitate management reviews, a color scheme shown in Fig. 2 is defined [1], [2] below due to the many WAT parameters to be compared:

a)
Green (\$\rightarrow\$ good matching): \${\rm sameness}\geq 98\%\$

b)
Yellow (\$\rightarrow\$ medium matching): \$90\%\leq{\rm sameness}<98\%\$

c)
Red (\$\rightarrow\$ poor matching): \${\rm sameness}<90\%\$



Fig. 1.

references.text: E. Wang, Proceedings of Hawaii International Conference on Statistics 2002, 2002-June-59.

references.title: SamenessAn Equivalency Index of Products, Processes and Services

context.text: To compare process parameters, Wang [1] proposed an index, “sameness” (whose corresponding US patent was filed and granted in 2004 [2]), in 2002, and he defined “sameness” as the “normalized” sum of the integral (both shaded areas in Fig. 1) under both distributions from a predetermined lower limit “C” to upper limit “D” as in Fig. 1, where “C” is the lower \$3\sigma\$ control limit of one population (Fab A in Fig. 1), and “D” is the upper \$3\sigma\$ control limit of the other (Fab B in Fig. 1).

Fig. 1.

references.text: E. Wang, SamenessAn Equivalency Index of Products Processes and Services, granted on September 2004.

references.title: Statistical Methods for Survival Data Analysis

context.text: There are abundant statistical theories [3]–[5] to compare estimated distribution parameters, distribution spreads, mean lifetimes, or percentages failing during warranty, by statistical inferences at certain confidence levels.

references.text: E. T. Lee, J. W. Wang, Statistical Methods for Survival Data Analysis, pp. 243-255, 2003, Wiley-Interscience.

references.title: Accelerated Testing: Statistical Models, Test Plans, and Data Analyses

context.text: There are abundant statistical theories [3]–[4][5] to compare estimated distribution parameters, distribution spreads, mean lifetimes, or percentages failing during warranty, by statistical inferences at certain confidence levels.

references.text: W. Nelson, Accelerated Testing: Statistical Models Test Plans and Data Analyses, pp. 425-450, 2004, John Wiley & Sons.

references.title: Reliability and Life Testing Handbook

context.text: There are abundant statistical theories [3]–[5] to compare estimated distribution parameters, distribution spreads, mean lifetimes, or percentages failing during warranty, by statistical inferences at certain confidence levels.

A conventional test on comparing mean lives [5] was to compare two different products using some characteristic lifetimes, such as the MTTF (Mean Time To Failure) of two Weibull distributions with the same shape parameter.

references.text: D. Kececioglu, Reliability and Life Testing Handbook, pp. 525-565, 2002, PTR Prentice Hall.

references.title: A two-sample test for reliability comparison

context.text: However, these methods are limited only to indicate whether the observed differences are \$s\$-significant [6], and can only deal with certain known distributions.

references.text: M. Sirvanci, "A two-sample test for reliability comparison", Quality Engineering, vol. 16, no. 4, pp. 535-540, 2004.

context.text: The \${\rm t}_{0.1\%}\$ from a single test with a given sample size is compared against the pre-specified requirement [7].
In the microelectronics industry, the extrapolated lifetime at a probability of 0.1% \$({\rm t}_{0.1\%})\$ is more widely used than the MTTF [7].

references.title: Statistical Models and Methods for Lifetime Data

context.text: The methods of constructing the CDF, such as Bernard's approximation, can be found in [8].

references.text: J. F. Lawless, Statistical Models and Methods for Lifetime Data, 2003, Wiley-Interscience.

ieee.displayText: Yefim Haim Michlin, Dov Ingman, Lilach Levin-David, "Sequential Test for Reliability Under Allowance for Target Uncertainty", Reliability IEEE Transactions on, vol. 61, pp. 1019-1029, 2012, ISSN 0018-9529.

ieee.title: Optimum Degradation Tests for Comparison of Products
ieee.displayText: Guangbin Yang, "Optimum Degradation Tests for Comparison of Products", Reliability IEEE Transactions on, vol. 61, pp. 220-226, 2012, ISSN 0018-9529.
